HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 26, 1927

VOL. XXXI, No. 47
BARNSTORMER PLAY TO
FEATURE ALUMNI DAY
PROGRAM
Lacrosse Game and Dance Also Scheduled for June Week Festivities on
Saturday, June 11

Of especial interest to the Hopkins alumni is the program of
events planned for June 11 by the
June Week Committee.
At 3.30 on that afternoon the
winner of the Mount WashingtonL'Hirondelle lacrosse game will
meet the champion of the Metropolitan Lacrosse League in the last
match of the season at Homewood
Field. The presence of many former Hopkins stars on the squads of
each of the Baltimore teams should
prove to be a big drawing card for
the "old grads."
•

Barnstormers Play

In the evening, the Barnstormers Club will present "Another Way
Out" in the Civil Engineering
building as its part of the "activiI. Evans
ty night" program.
Rodgers, who will direct the production, has selected a cast which
will have the unique distinction of
utilizing girls from Goucher in the
female parts. The play, itself, has
been previously used by the Barnstormers in their fall try-outs.
"Another Way Out" is based on
the Bohemian existence of a modern writer and his mistress, a your
artist, with whom he is living—
much to the disgust of their housekeeper. The interest in the plot
centers around their mutual agreement to make love to the first woman and man, respectively, that they
meet. Earle Grey Sands, who last
appeared in campus dramatics in
"His Majesty Bunker Bean," will
Play the lead as the exotic young
author. John Boynton has been selected for the 'part of the handsome
Young book agent who is mistaken
for a model and made love to by
the artist according to her agree-.
ment.

THEY'RE SOMETIMES TOO HUMAN
Despite the mourning among a few at Hopkins because of
the apparent decline of debating here, we see that the good old
art still flourishes in some quarters. According to a news item
we read the other day, over a thousand people paid to hear Mr.
Clarence Darrow exchange words with Mr. Wayne B. Wheeler
upon the merits of the Prohibition.
The attendance at a debate appears to be dependent not
only upon the excellence of the debaters themselves, but also
upon the subject of the argument. What undergraduate, for example, would want to listen to two teams of three men each'
discourse upon the political status of Baluchistan? But if the
debate dealt with stage and book censorship and promised to be
overflowing with racy erotic passages, the hall would probably
be filled.
All of which proves once more that an undergraduate is a
very, very human animal, and not an object of special interest
to be iSolated and studied much as a biologist studies a guinea pig.

THE HALF WAY MARK
Early season predictions assumed that if the lacrosse team.
. could pass the half-way mark with victories over Yale and Army,
success for the remainder of the schedule should follow. Therefore, according to .this, reasoning, Swarthmore, Navy, St. Johns,
and Maryland should pave the way for. the.second championship
in two years.
For several years previous b 1926, a very similar -condition
existed. The team would get off to a good start, become highly
confident,—and then break. In 19+26, however, there was no
break, and though each succee4ng- game was a climax in itself,
no game was allowed to become an anti-climax. The result is that
the members of the 1926 team wear little gold medals on' their
watch fobs.
1927 can take either course. Though Army was supposed to
be the chief stumbling-block, Navy and Maryland still loom large
upon the horizon. And Maryland seems to get better each week.
The remainder of the season, in light of these facts; will be
the really brilliant part from the viewpoint of a lacrosse enthusiast. A team that has won thirteen consecutive games struggles to keep its slate clean against the best the opposition can
offer. Win or lose, we should see some high-class lacrosse during May.
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of
Irvin B..Hoffman as Assistant Business Manager.

UND THEWORLD

Youthful Suicides
Will Durant has joined that group of writers who
make Cosmopolitan the most alert magazine in
America. How deeply he has thought out the
subject he writes of is shown by these questions:
"What happens to thefamous'firstlaw of nature'
in these instances? What impulse is it that is
so strong that all the instincts, all the hunger
for possession and love and power crumble
at its coming? How can the will to live lose its
omnipotence when the body is still young, and
the blood courses freshly through full veins?"
And his answer is so coldly logical, that it is
sensational by virtue of its simplicity.

You use automatic machines. You employ
quantity methods of production. But how
about your fuel?
Remember this. Any uncertainty in the
application of heat, strikes at the very heart
of quantity production!
Automatic machines call for automatic fuel.
Gas is just that. It is 100% controllable.
With gas, you can increase or decrease the
quantity of heat—instantly—to suit the exact
speed of production.
The result is maintenance of production
schedules, uniformity of product, and fullest
economy. Have you yet investigated the
merits of gas for your plant?
Write to the American Gas Association for
information on what gas is doing for others
in your line of business.

JAY NETMEN TO BATTLE
ST. JOHNS TEAM THIS
AFTERNOON
Hopkins Court Squad to Meet Catholic
University Squad at Homewood
Tomorrow

Johns Hopkins's tennis team, led
by George Hebner, Jr., meets St.
Johns at Homewood this afternoon at 2.30.
St. Johns will present about the
same line-up as they did last year,
when Hebner and his cohorts took
them into camp with an 8-1 drubbing. Hopkins swept the singles
and lost only one double match.
Tomorrow the team will tackle
Catholic University, followed by
Georgetown. Both will present
formidable opposition and brilliant
exhibitions of tennis should be in
order.
Georgetown University boasts of
Emmett Pare, nationally known
junior player, who recently paired
with William T. Tilden in his
Southern campaign. Francis Hunter, partner to Tilden in his
European invasion which, he has
just undertaken, defeated Pare only
after a heart-breaking three-set
struggle. Pare will play number
one. Pare brings with him a team
that is out to avenge the defeat
they suffered last year in Baltimore,
5-2, although Hopkins was given a
dose of its own medicine in a return match when Georgetown beat
the Homewood team, 4-3.
Catholic University, with practically the same team of last year,
will afford Hopkins another chance
to test the strength of this season's
tennis team. C. U. played the varsity tennis team to a tie score in
Washington last year.
The prospects for a strong team
are very bright at present. Two
letter men are left from last year,

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 26, 1927

VOL. XXXI, No. 47
BARNSTORMER PLAY TO
FEATURE ALUMNI DAY
PROGRAM
Lacrosse Game and Dance Also Scheduled for June Week Festivities on
Saturday, June 11

Of especial interest to the Hopkins alumni is the program of
events planned for June 11 by the
June Week Committee.
At 3.30 on that afternoon the
winner of the Mount WashingtonL'Hirondelle lacrosse game will
meet the champion of the Metropolitan Lacrosse League in the last
match of the season at Homewood
Field. The presence of many former Hopkins stars on the squads of
each of the Baltimore teams should
prove to be a big drawing card for
the "old grads."
•

Barnstormers Play

In the evening, the Barnstormers Club will present "Another Way
Out" in the Civil Engineering
building as its part of the "activiI. Evans
ty night" program.
Rodgers, who will direct the production, has selected a cast which
will have the unique distinction of
utilizing girls from Goucher in the
female parts. The play, itself, has
been previously used by the Barnstormers in their fall try-outs.
"Another Way Out" is based on
the Bohemian existence of a modern writer and his mistress, a your
artist, with whom he is living—
much to the disgust of their housekeeper. The interest in the plot
centers around their mutual agreement to make love to the first woman and man, respectively, that they
meet. Earle Grey Sands, who last
appeared in campus dramatics in
"His Majesty Bunker Bean," will
Play the lead as the exotic young
author. John Boynton has been selected for the 'part of the handsome
Young book agent who is mistaken
for a model and made love to by
the artist according to her agree-.
ment.

popular

the

the Swarthmore game in the
afternoon at Homewood
should (..raw a crowd. The
tax, as usual, will be $1
either couple or stag.

THEY'RE SOMETIMES TOO HUMAN
Despite the mourning among a few at Hopkins because of
the apparent decline of debating here, we see that the good old
art still flourishes in some quarters. According to a news item
we read the other day, over a thousand people paid to hear Mr.
Clarence Darrow exchange words with Mr. Wayne B. Wheeler
upon the merits of the Prohibition.
The attendance at a debate appears to be dependent not
only upon the excellence of the debaters themselves, but also
upon the subject of the argument. What undergraduate, for example, would want to listen to two teams of three men each'
discourse upon the political status of Baluchistan? But if the
debate dealt with stage and book censorship and promised to be
overflowing with racy erotic passages, the hall would probably
be filled.
All of which proves once more that an undergraduate is a
very, very human animal, and not an object of special interest
to be iSolated and studied much as a biologist studies a guinea pig.

THE HALF WAY MARK
Early season predictions assumed that if the lacrosse team.
. could pass the half-way mark with victories over Yale and Army,
success for the remainder of the schedule should follow. Therefore, according to .this, reasoning, Swarthmore, Navy, St. Johns,
and Maryland should pave the way for. the.second championship
in two years.
For several years previous b 1926, a very similar -condition
existed. The team would get off to a good start, become highly
confident,—and then break. In 19+26, however, there was no
break, and though each succee4ng- game was a climax in itself,
no game was allowed to become an anti-climax. The result is that
the members of the 1926 team wear little gold medals on' their
watch fobs.
1927 can take either course. Though Army was supposed to
be the chief stumbling-block, Navy and Maryland still loom large
upon the horizon. And Maryland seems to get better each week.
The remainder of the season, in light of these facts; will be
the really brilliant part from the viewpoint of a lacrosse enthusiast. A team that has won thirteen consecutive games struggles to keep its slate clean against the best the opposition can
offer. Win or lose, we should see some high-class lacrosse during May.

Youthful Suicides
Will Durant has joined that group of writers who
make Cosmopolitan the most alert magazine in
America. How deeply he has thought out the
subject he writes of is shown by these questions:
"What happens to thefamous'firstlaw of nature'
in these instances? What impulse is it that is
so strong that all the instincts, all the hunger
for possession and love and power crumble
at its coming? How can the will to live lose its
omnipotence when the body is still young, and
the blood courses freshly through full veins?"
And his answer is so coldly logical, that it is
sensational by virtue of its simplicity.

You use automatic machines. You employ
quantity methods of production. But how
about your fuel?
Remember this. Any uncertainty in the
application of heat, strikes at the very heart
of quantity production!
Automatic machines call for automatic fuel.
Gas is just that. It is 100% controllable.
With gas, you can increase or decrease the
quantity of heat—instantly—to suit the exact
speed of production.
The result is maintenance of production
schedules, uniformity of product, and fullest
economy. Have you yet investigated the
merits of gas for your plant?
Write to the American Gas Association for
information on what gas is doing for others
in your line of business.

JAY NETMEN TO BATTLE
ST. JOHNS TEAM THIS
AFTERNOON
Hopkins Court Squad to Meet Catholic
University Squad at Homewood
Tomorrow

Johns Hopkins's tennis team, led
by George Hebner, Jr., meets St.
Johns at Homewood this afternoon at 2.30.
St. Johns will present about the
same line-up as they did last year,
when Hebner and his cohorts took
them into camp with an 8-1 drubbing. Hopkins swept the singles
and lost only one double match.
Tomorrow the team will tackle
Catholic University, followed by
Georgetown. Both will present
formidable opposition and brilliant
exhibitions of tennis should be in
order.
Georgetown University boasts of
Emmett Pare, nationally known
junior player, who recently paired
with William T. Tilden in his
Southern campaign. Francis Hunter, partner to Tilden in his
European invasion which, he has
just undertaken, defeated Pare only
after a heart-breaking three-set
struggle. Pare will play number
one. Pare brings with him a team
that is out to avenge the defeat
they suffered last year in Baltimore,
5-2, although Hopkins was given a
dose of its own medicine in a return match when Georgetown beat
the Homewood team, 4-3.
Catholic University, with practically the same team of last year,
will afford Hopkins another chance
to test the strength of this season's
tennis team. C. U. played the varsity tennis team to a tie score in
Washington last year.
The prospects for a strong team
are very bright at present. Two
letter men are left from last year,
Hebner and Levenstein. However, new material with very :promising possibilities is in prospect for
this season.

first match of the year is composed

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 26, 1927
RIFLE TEAM TO HOLD
CUP CONTEST SOON
Due to the Hopkins-Vale
lacrosse game, the rifle team
did not compete in the Abercrombie contest, several weeks
ago. According to Lieutenant Offley, the team has not
as yet set the day upon which
the match will take place. The
contest will be open only to
the members of the team, the
winner receiving a cup to be
presented by Dr. Abercrombie
at the last R. 0. T. C. drill
of the year.

PHI BETA KAPPA ELECTS
TWENTY-EIGHT NEW
MEMBERS
Graduate Schools of Medicine
and Philosophy

Twenty-eight new members were
elected to Phi Beta Kappa at a
meeting .of the society held on
April 13. At the same meeting
officers for the ensuing year were
chosen. The new officers are Dr.
William W. Ford, president; Dr.
Herbert S. Jennings, vice-president; Dr. Carol Van Buren Wight,
secretary, and Dr. Broadus Mitchell, treasurer.

COMPLETED HULLABALOO BOASTS GREAT
ORIGINALITY AND MANY FEATURE

Real Work Begins

When the train reached Blue
Ridge Summit the embryo scientists were packed into two trucks
and an automobile and the long
expected geology trip had begun
in earnest. During the morning
the golf links at Monterey (Pa.)
and the section around charmian
were explored. An especially delightful view of the surrounding
mountains was obtained from the
porch of the Clermont Hotel.
After lunch the trucks were again
loaded and the crowd left for the
Devil's Race Course, a broad field
of rocks upon which it is said that
Satan delighted to sprint. Next
Buena Vista springs was visited
and finally the truck drove up in
front of the Anthony Wayne
Hotel in the little town of
Waynesboro.
